newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Rights group rejects Burmese government criticism.
newsitem.headline: Rights group rejects Burmese government criticism.

text.p: The London-based human rights group Amnesty International on Thursday dismissed Burmese criticism of its latest report on the country and reiterated a call for Asian nations to isolate Rangoon.

"The Burmese government's strong reaction to our report shows just how sensitive the authorities are to criticism of their human rights record," the group said in a statement from its European Union office in Brussels.
"This shows the importance of the members of ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) and other governments continuing to put pressure on the Burmese authorities."
Rangoon on Wednesday dismissed an Amnesty report on human rights in Burma as "ridiculous", accusing the group of being a propaganda machine for anti-government organisations.
In its report, Amnesty said political repression and human rights violations in Burma last year reached their highest levels since the violent state suppression of a popular uprising in 1988.
The group said more than 2,000 people were arrested in 1996 simply for calling for human rights reforms and that opposition party members were attacked by organised mobs.

Amnesty has been lobbying hard to get a meeting of the European Union and ASEAN currently being held in Singapore to come out with a strong statement on Burma, but the issue has split Asian and European nations.
Burma is likely soon to be made a member of ASEAN -- possibly before the end of this year -- despite EU leaders warning that this could "complicate" relations.
